unnormalised: A recent study conducted by the Indian Statistical Institute (ISI) Kolkata reveals intriguing insights into student performance in competitive exams. Analyzing data from over 10,000 students across various states, researchers found that students spending >4 hrs/day on self-study had a 30% higher chance of clearing the JEE advanced compared to those studying <2 hrs/day.
normalised: A recent study conducted by the I-S-I Kolkata reveals intriguing insights into student performance in competitive exams. Analyzing data from over ten thousand students across various states, researchers found that students spending greater than four hours per day on self-study had a thirty percent higher chance of clearing the J-E-E advanced compared to those studying less than two hours per day.

unnormalised: The study also investigated the correlation between socioeconomic factors and academic outcomes. It indicated that students from families with an annual income exceeding â‚¹5 lakh had a 20% greater likelihood of scoring above the 90th percentile in the NEET exam. Furthermore, the research delved into regional disparities, noting a standard deviation of 15 marks in the CAT exam scores across different metropolitan cities.
normalised: The study also investigated the correlation between socioeconomic factors and academic outcomes. It indicated that students from families with an annual income exceeding rupee five lakh had a twenty percent greater likelihood of scoring above the ninetieth percentile in the N-E-E-T exam. Furthermore, the research delved into regional disparities, noting a standard deviation of fifteen marks in the C-A-T exam scores across different metropolitan cities.

unnormalised: These findings highlight the importance of dedicated study habits and address the impact of socioeconomic background on educational success. Dr. Meena Sharma, the lead researcher, emphasized the need for targeted interventions to bridge the gap and ensure equitable opportunities for all students appearing for these national level exams.
